awd_titl_txt: The CryptoClub: Extending Learning with Student-Generated Tutorials
awd_abstract_narration:
In existing CryptoClub after school programs, middle school students use mathematics to make and break secret codes.  The CryptoClub website has tools for encrypting, messages to crack, treasure hunts and other activities.  In this project, the learning in fifteen Crypto Clubs is extended by having the students generate tutorials that explain how they solve mathematics and cryptographic problems.  The flexibility of the after school setting provides the opportunity to experiment with content and technology.  Student-friendly ways to create the tutorials are developed and best practices for incorporating tutorial making in CryptoClub programs are investigated.  A collection of vetted online tutorials about mathematics and cryptography created by students and teachers is to be available to all on the CryptoClub website.  At least 15 teachers are to be trained to assist their students in developing tutorials. These teachers can then use this learning technique as they teach other mathematics topics.  

The research investigates the features of the tutorials that students and teachers consider to be appealing and easy to learn from.  The kinds of mathematics problems that make helpful tutorials and promote communications skills are studied.  By focusing on specific topics and using students within the same clubs as control, the project leadership can conduct a controlled study of learning that occurs on those topics and thus investigate whether the students learn mathematics from the experience of developing video tutorials.  The project also considers the technology and software that facilitate the development of the tutorials and the system for online sharing, rating and sorting of video tutorials that promote the development, submission and use of the tutorials.  Evaluation is done by an independent evaluator and an advisory board.  

Students will develop technical literacy and skills in mathematics, computer technology and communications and become aware of cryptography as a possible STEM career as well.  The project deepens students' understanding of mathematical reasoning, supports their development of self-efficacy and increases their interest in STEM and STEM careers that use mathematics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CryptoClub Project develops materials and provides professional development for teaching cryptography and mathematics in middle-grade classes and afterschool programs. This ITEST project focused on CryptoClubs whose teachers wanted to include video tutorial-making as an additional club activity to extend student learning. In these clubs, students spent some of their time doing regular CryptoClub activities and some making video tutorials that explained their solutions to mathematics and cryptography problems. An evaluation done by the American Institutes for Research (AIR) found that students and their teachers enjoyed the video-tutorial making process and that teachers felt it encouraged students to think through the process of solving the puzzles.

Over the first 3 years of the grant the project trained eleven teachers. Approximately 200 students participated in their clubs and submitted one hundred nineteen videos for the project to review. In addition, project staff also learned about video tutorials and have now developed over 90 video tutorials; some are available to teachers on the resource section of CryptoClub.uchicago.edu, some will be posted on the website CryptoClub.org to aid student users, and others will be used in online training modules for CryptoClub teachers, that are currently under development. 

The project held teacher training workshops each summer for three years that included opportunities for participants to discuss sample video tutorials and to make and edit their own tutorials using a variety of software packages. Teachers made narrated screen captures of website activities (Jing software package), recorded handwriting on PDF backgrounds on iPads (Explain Everything app), and recorded paper-and-pencil written solutions (HoverCam document camera and iPad cameras). 

Students made tutorials in their CryptoClubs using a variety of technologies. Their methods included narrated screen capture of CryptoClub website activities, recordings with My Vittle Ap on iPads, and recordings of presentations on document readers. We initially requested that videos not present images of the students for privacy reasons. But many students preferred to appear in their videos, so some used phones and laptop cameras. In the first year, students made their tutorials on any topic they chose. Our early observations and initial findings from the AIR evaluation indicated that students needed more guidance on topics and teachers needed more guidance on how to lead tutorial clubs. Thus the project made specific suggestions of appropriate problems for students to choose from and developed explicit protocols for teachers to follow when discussing, preparing, and sharing tutorials. 

Developing rubrics for evaluating videos became part of the project. Working with our evaluation team (AIR) we refined a rubric to be used by their team in evaluating the student tutorials. This rubric was also used by program staff and teachers to guide students? development of tutorial videos.  In some CryptoClubs, students also participated in making rubrics, as they helped each other perfect their video efforts. In the end, video tutorials were judged by production quality, mathematics and cryptography, and explanation quality. Results of the AIR evaluation indicate that students generally did a better job of demonstrating their knowledge of cryptography and math concepts in their videos than in using effective teaching techniques.

To motivate students to make and complete their tutorials, the project offered two video-tutorial contests. Each CryptoClub was invited to choose and submit what its students considered the best three tutorials made by their club members. Eleven videos were submitted to the first contest, with an additional 33 submitted to the research project, and certificates were awarded for the most advanced cipher cracked, best explanation of mathematics, most innovative cracking strategy, and best demonstration using the tools on CryptoClub.org. The project was pleased to give awards to every club that had submitted videos.  

The project had broader impacts beyond cryptography-tutorial making. Some teachers who used tutorial making as an educational strategy in their CryptoClubs also used it in their regular mathematics classes. As students worked to develop tutorial-making skills in CryptoClub, they also developed important workforce skills, including mathematics skills, computer technology skills, and communication skills.  Learning cryptography creates an awareness of cryptography as a possible STEM career and has the broader impact of preparing students to be citizens who are aware of modern issues such as those related to Internet security. Further, the project provided academic enrichment to students attending high-poverty and low-performing schools, since it was implemented in a variety of afterschool settings, including 21st Century Community Learning Centers and Chicago Public Schools, which serve this population of students. 

Further findings from the AIR Evaluation can be found in a summary report, Problem Solving on Camera: Evaluation of Student-Made Tutorials for CryptoClub.
